articles.headline: Sainthood of Junípero Serra Reopens Wounds of Colonialism in California
articles.snippet: The legacy of Father Serra, who was canonized last week, has been disputed by Native Americans who say he oppressed their forebears as he worked to convert them to Catholicism.
articles.abstract: The legacy of Father Serra, who was canonized last week, has been disputed by Native Americans who say he oppressed their forebears as he worked to convert them to Catholicism.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARMEL-BY-THE-SEA, Calif. — A group of teenagers huddled at the foot of a statue of Junípero Serra at the Carmel Mission on Monday, there to pay homage to the Spaniard who helped colonize California in the 18th century. Only a day earlier, vandals had toppled the six-foot figure and doused it with paint, writing “saint of genocide” on a nearby triangle of stone. But now the statue was upright and scrubbed clean for visitors.

articles.headline: Ralph Lauren, Creator of Fashion Empire, Is Stepping Down as C.E.O.
articles.snippet: The designer will turn over management of his fashion empire to Stefan Larsson, president of Old Navy, but will stay active in the company in new roles.
articles.abstract: The designer will turn over management of his fashion empire to Stefan Larsson, president of Old Navy, but will stay active in the company in new roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ralph Lauren, the quintessential American designer who built a fashion empire based on sweeping fantasies of country-club prep and the Wild West, is stepping down from his post as chief executive of the company.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Getting to $100 Billion in Climate Change Aid
articles.snippet: Far from meeting a commitment of $100 billion a year by 2020 for developing nations, the richest countries have trouble defining what that would mean.
articles.abstract: Far from meeting a commitment of $100 billion a year by 2020 for developing nations, the richest countries have trouble defining what that would mean.

articles.headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Brings Temporary Foreign Workers to U.S. to Move Jobs Overseas
articles.snippet: A federal program intended to bring in workers with special skills is being used by some American companies to hire and train other foreign workers.
articles.abstract: A federal program intended to bring in workers with special skills is being used by some American companies to hire and train other foreign workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAYNE, N.J. — When Congress designed temporary work visa programs, the idea was to bring in foreigners with specialized, hard-to-find skills who would help American companies grow, creating jobs to expand the economy. Now, though, some companies are bringing in workers on those visas to help move jobs out of the country.

articles.headline: Behaviorists Show the U.S. How to Improve Government Operations
articles.snippet: A year-old effort by the Obama administration is applying academic research on human behavior to the business of running the government.
articles.abstract: A year-old effort by the Obama administration is applying academic research on human behavior to the business of running the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government found a clever way to make a little extra money last summer.

articles.headline: Fiat Chrysler Concedes Violating Rule on Reporting Death and Injury Claims
articles.snippet: The announcement comes as federal regulators are stepping up oversight of automakers for safety problems and environmental issues.
articles.abstract: The announcement comes as federal regulators are stepping up oversight of automakers for safety problems and environmental issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Federal regulators said on Tuesday that Fiat Chrysler Automobiles had significantly underreported to regulators the number of death and injury claims linked to possible defects in its cars.

articles.headline: Russia Buildup Seen as Fanning Flames in Syria
articles.snippet: On the long list of Moscow’s goals in building up its military presence in Syria, taking on the Islamic State is but one entry, foreign policy experts say.
articles.abstract: On the long list of Moscow’s goals in building up its military presence in Syria, taking on the Islamic State is but one entry, foreign policy experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia’s military buildup in Syria will probably prolong the life of the beleaguered government of President Bashar al-Assad, Pentagon officials and foreign policy experts say, but is unlikely to be a major factor in the campaign to defeat the Islamic State, and could further inflame — and lengthen — the conflict.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: John Kerry Rushes In Where Obama Will Not Tread
articles.snippet: The idea that solving the crisis in Syria, or any diplomatic dilemma, may be elusive, perhaps even impossible, is no deterrent to Secretary of State John Kerry.
articles.abstract: The idea that solving the crisis in Syria, or any diplomatic dilemma, may be elusive, perhaps even impossible, is no deterrent to Secretary of State John Kerry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For four years, President Obama has watched the civil war in Syria with deep frustration. It is, he tells advisers, an intractable situation, though he uses a grittier word. The best the United States can do in the short term, he says, is manage it as much as possible.

articles.headline: Drone-for-Hire Business Makes Big Bet on Industry
articles.snippet: Robert Wolf’s advisory firm plans to announce it is spinning off its drone-services arm into a separate company, which is positioned like none other to thrive in the nascent drone market.
articles.abstract: Robert Wolf’s advisory firm plans to announce it is spinning off its drone-services arm into a separate company, which is positioned like none other to thrive in the nascent drone market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The business of drones has ascended into the stratosphere, as investors have poured hundreds of millions of dollars into the tiny unmanned aircraft in hopes of turning them into big business.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Russians Strike Targets in Syria, but Not ISIS Areas
articles.snippet: Russian aircraft carried out a bombing attack against Syrian opposition fighters, including at least one group trained by the C.I.A., eliciting angry protests from American officials.
articles.abstract: Russian aircraft carried out a bombing attack against Syrian opposition fighters, including at least one group trained by the C.I.A., eliciting angry protests from American officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian aircraft carried out a bombing attack against Syrian opposition fighters on Wednesday, including at least one group trained by the C.I.A., eliciting angry protests from American officials and plunging the complex sectarian war there into dangerous new territory.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Michael R. Gordon and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: VW Scandal Shows a Need for More Tech, Not Less
articles.snippet: The world is in an uncomfortable lull between the mechanical automobile age and full-fledged computerized intelligence in our cars.
articles.abstract: The world is in an uncomfortable lull between the mechanical automobile age and full-fledged computerized intelligence in our cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: You could be forgiven for reacting to the Volkswagen scandal by yearning for the halcyon era of dumb cars. Remember when our rides weren’t controlled by secret, corrupt software — when your father’s Oldsmobile was solidly mechanical and so simple in its operation that even a government regulator could understand it?

articles.headline: ‘Survivor’ Defies Gravity to Hang On as CBS Ratings Stalwart
articles.snippet: The reality show, beginning its 16th year on the air, has managed to keep drawing a steady number of viewers, even as its contemporaries have faded.
articles.abstract: The reality show, beginning its 16th year on the air, has managed to keep drawing a steady number of viewers, even as its contemporaries have faded.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, “CSI,” the CBS drama starring Ted Danson, quietly ended its 15-year run with a two-hour series finale. Next year, “American Idol,” the talent competition that has been on the air since 2002, will end after years of declining ratings.

articles.headline: Can Kevin McCarthy, House Speaker Favorite, Go From Buddy to Boss?
articles.snippet: In just the past 48 hours, Mr. McCarthy insulted Speaker John A. Boehner and suggested a taxpayer-funded committee was designed to harm the political fortunes of Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.abstract: In just the past 48 hours, Mr. McCarthy insulted Speaker John A. Boehner and suggested a taxpayer-funded committee was designed to harm the political fortunes of Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy of California has built a loyal following among House Republicans by calling them up just to gab, giving them special jackets when they joined his vote-whipping team and telling them their ideas are fantastic, even after telling the last guy who left his office that his (completely opposite) idea was great, too.
